Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as there is no evidence provided to verify the authenticity of the Parler post or the involvement of Acting Pardon Attorney Rosalind Sargent-Burns.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that President Donald Trump was considering pardoning his supporters without providing any concrete evidence or official statement.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the statement from the Department of Justice, which denies the involvement of the Office of the Pardon Attorney in any efforts to pardon individuals involved in the Capitol insurrection.
Exaggerate: The claim may be considered an exaggeration as it presents an alleged scheme by President Trump to pardon his supporters without providing substantial evidence.
Exist alternative explanation: There is a possibility of alternative explanations, such as the Parler post being fabricated or misattributed to Acting Pardon Attorney Rosalind Sargent-Burns, which would question the credibility of the claim.
Understate: There is no evidence to suggest that the claim understates any aspect of the situation.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times as it relies on unverified information and lacks official confirmation or support.
